Issues.Title: fix(ivy): handle empty bindings in template type checker
Issues.Body:
When a template contains a binding without a value, the template parser
creates an `EmptyExpr` node. This would previously be translated into
an `undefined` value, which would cause a crash downstream as `undefined`
is not included in the allowed type, so it was not handled properly.

This commit prevents the crash by returning an actual expression for empty
bindings.

Fixes #30076
Fixes #30929

---

This is a new PR for #30938 without the breaking changes regarding the `AstVisitor`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): handle empty bindings in template type checker" (#31594)

Issues.Title: Migrating to ChangeStrategy.OnPush makes performance even worse.
Issues.Body:
We have a real content Single page application that is not fully adopting `ChangeDectionStragtegy.OnPush`, but after I update the component `ChangeDectionStrategy` to `OnPush`, it makes the performance even worse.

I am comparing by `ChangeDetectionPerfRecord` (ng.profiler.timeChangeDetection)

*** before ***
```
ng.profiler.timeChangeDetection()
platform-browser.js:2216 ran 573 change detection cycles
platform-browser.js:2217 0.87 ms per check
```

*** after ***
```
ng.profiler.timeChangeDetection()
platform-browser.js:2216 ran 862 change detection cycles
platform-browser.js:2217 0.58 ms per check
```

Another extreme case 

*** before ***
```
ng.profiler.timeChangeDetection()
platform-browser.js:2216 ran 150 change detection cycles
platform-browser.js:2217 3.34 ms per check
```

*** after ***
```
ng.profiler.timeChangeDetection()
platform-browser.js:2216 ran 1869 change detection cycles
platform-browser.js:2217 0.27 ms per check
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Migrating to ChangeStrategy.OnPush makes performance even worse." (#31593)

Issues.Title: Compiler DI errors are difficult to interpret
Issues.Body:
**Angular debugging is bad**

Best example: 

> dependency injection errors

```
Uncaught Error: Can't resolve all parameters for FormComponent: ([object Object], [object Object], [object Object], [object Object], ?, [object Object], ?, ... and a lot more parameters).
    at syntaxError (compiler.js:2409)
    at CompileMetadataResolver._getDependenciesMetadata (compiler.js:21311)
    at CompileMetadataResolver._getTypeMetadata (compiler.js:21203)
    at CompileMetadataResolver.getNonNormalizedDirectiveMetadata (compiler.js:20822)
    at CompileMetadataResolver._getEntryComponentMetadata (compiler.js:21407)
    at compiler.js:21398
    at Array.forEach (<anonymous>)
    at CompileMetadataResolver._getEntryComponentsFromProvider (compiler.js:21397)
    at compiler.js:21370
    at Array.forEach (<anonymous>)
```

How i'm suppose to know what exact **parameter** is cannot be resolved and why?

```
constructor(
        private snackBar: MatSnackBar,
        @Inject(BackendService) private backend: BackendService,
        @Inject(ChromeMessengerService) private chromeMessenger: ChromeMessengerService,
        @Inject(DateTimeService) private datetime: DateTimeService,
        @Inject(SettingsService) private settings: SettingsService,
        @Inject(StoreService) private store: StoreService,
        ... other dozens of services ...
    ) {
```

Why it points me to his modules instead of error in my code?
```
syntaxError | @ | compiler.js:2409
-- | -- | --
¬† | CompileMetadataResolver._getDependenciesMetadata | @ | compiler.js:21311
¬† | CompileMetadataResolver._getTypeMetadata | @ | compiler.js:21203
¬† | CompileMetadataResolver.getNonNormalizedDirectiveMetadata | @ | compiler.js:20822
¬† | CompileMetadataResolver._getEntryComponentMetadata | @ | compiler.js:21407
¬† | (anonymous) | @ | compiler.js:21398
¬† | CompileMetadataResolver._getEntryComponentsFromProvider | @ | compiler.js:21397
¬† | (anonymous) | @ | compiler.js:21370
¬† | CompileMetadataResolver._getProvidersMetadata | @ | compiler.js:21333
¬† | (anonymous) | @ | compiler.js:21335
¬† | CompileMetadataResolver._getProvidersMetadata | @ | compiler.js:21333
¬† | (anonymous) | @ | compiler.js:20955
¬† | CompileMetadataResolver.getNgModuleMetadata | @ | compiler.js:20946
¬† | CompileMetadataResolver.getNgModuleSummary | @ | compiler.js:20881
¬† | (anonymous) | @ | compiler.js:20968
¬† | CompileMetadataResolver.getNgModuleMetadata | @ | compiler.js:20946
¬† | JitCompiler._loadModules | @ | compiler.js:27106
¬† | JitCompiler._compileModuleAndComponents | @ | compiler.js:27087
¬† | JitCompiler.compileModuleAsync | @ | compiler.js:27047
¬† | CompilerImpl.compileModuleAsync | @ | platform-browser-dynamic.js:143
¬† | compileNgModuleFactory__PRE_R3__ | @ | core.js:27089
¬† | PlatformRef.bootstrapModule | @ | core.js:27301
¬† | ./src/app/grabber/app.main.ts | @ | app.main.ts:15
¬† | __webpack_require__ | @ | bootstrap:19
¬† | (anonymous) | @ | bootstrap:83
¬† | (anonymous) | @ | bootstrap:83
```

My code is only in `app.main.ts:15` and that is only application entry:
```
platformBrowserDynamic().bootstrapModule(AppModule);
```

So it clearly tell me: "The problem is somewhere in your app, but I don't give a fuck where it's exactly".

Thank you Angular, you're awesome.

Issues.Title: Error Stack as rewritten by Zone.js not recognized by Stackdriver
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by the zone.js package ### Is this a regression? Not to my knowledge. ### Description TL;DR Zone.js rewrites the error stack in a way that stackdriver doesn't recognize and event reports are bounced with 400 errors. Zone.js rewrites the `stack` property on errors to be zone aware: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/3166cffd28e12d882bef3e55472e0a50f4cfc6f5/packages/zone.js/lib/common/error-rewrite.ts#L132 In addition to "cleaning up extra frames", it appends the zone name in square brackets: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/3166cffd28e12d882bef3e55472e0a50f4cfc6f5/packages/zone.js/lib/common/error-rewrite.ts#L107-L108 This transforms a frame from: ``` at Class.method (filpath.ts:line:col) ``` to: ``` at Class.method (filpath.ts:line:col) [zoneName] ``` Stackdriver Error Reporting has [an endpoint for reporting events](https://cloud.google.com/error-reporting/reference/rest/v1beta1/projects.events/report). In order for an event to be successfully reported, the event must meet at least one of two criteria: 1. The event explicitly contains context.reportLocation, or 2. The event contains a message with a properly formatted stack trace. For JavaScript, the endpoint expects the message to "be the value of [error.stack](https://github.com/v8/v8/wiki/Stack-Trace-API) as returned by V8." When sending the zone.js rewritten stack as the message for an event, stackdriver responds with: ``` { "error": { "code": 400, "message": "ReportedErrorEvent.context must contain a location unless `message` contain an exception or stacktrace.", "status": "INVALID_ARGUMENT" } } ``` If instead I send error.originalStack as the message, the response is 200 and the event is reported. While there's no issue here that cannot be worked around, I think it's an unexpected gotcha that you cannot use error.stack in the message, particularly because this process of rewriting the stack isn't particularly easy to find in documentation. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Available by request. I believe I have already identified the root causes. ## üî• Exception or Error Noted above ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Latest

Issues.Title: Multiple instances of a web component with routing
Issues.Body:
I created a simple component with routing and bootstrapped this component using Angular Elements. I then included multiple instances of the resulting web component on a page:

Here is the demo: http://routerissue.s3-website.us-east-2.amazonaws.com
Here is the source: https://github.com/popsovy/RouterIssue

The problem is that only the last component receives the router-outlet, meaning it doesn't matter from which instance of the component I navigate from, the "routed to" component always gets loaded in the router-outlet of the **last instance** of the component on the page.

 I would expect that each instance of a web component should navigate to its own router-outlet.

Issues.Title: Auto-Emitting @Output-Variables
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
This feature request is for `@angular/core`


### Description
If I have a variable which is an `@Output` as well I often have code code cluttered like:

```js
this.isLoading = true
this.isLoadingChange.emit(true)
this.isLoadingError = false
this.isLoadingErrorChange.emit(false)

observable$.subscribe(
  () => {
    // ...
    this.isLoading = false
    this.isLoadingChange.emit(false)
  }, (error) => {
    // ...
    this.isLoading = false
    this.isLoadingChange.emit(false)
    this.isLoadingError = true
    this.isLoadingErrorChange.emit(true)
  }
)
```

My first approach to make this more DRY was creating setter/getter-methods for `isLoading` and `isLoadingChange` which automatically emit on `set`. This quickly became unsatisfying as a lot of boilerplate-code is needed for this solution as well:

```js
@Output() isLoadingChange = new EventEmitter<boolean>()
private _isLoading
public get isLoading(): boolean { return this._isLoading }
public set isLoading(isLoading: boolean) { 
  this._isLoading = isLoading
  this.isLoadingChange.emit(isLoading)
}
```

(For the sake of simplicity this is only the example for one variable.)


### Describe the solution you'd like

Disclaimer: I really have no experience of crafting new language-features in such a highly complex environment.

I would like a way of defining `@Output`s to emit automatically when their counterpart variable (without `Change` suffix) is being changed. The idea for the syntax I came up with is inspired by the options-object I can pass to the `@ViewChild`-decorator.

```js
public isLoading = true
// Or: @Input() isLoading = true
@Output('isLoading', { emitOnUpdate: true }) isLoadingChange = new EventEmitter<boolean>()
```

#### Notes

* Optionally another option `emitOnlyOnChange` could ensure that any value value is only emitted if it's not equal to its predecessor (`===`).
* Optionally another option `updateAsync` could ensure that the private assignment `this._isLoading = isLoading` is executed asynchronously. (Just like if you pass `true` to the `EventEmitter`-constructor.


Best regards, 
Dennis
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Auto-Emitting @Output-Variables" (#31582)

# üöÄ feature request
Would like [Deno](https://deno.land/) runtime support.

This is a new runtime that has was created by [Ryan Dahl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ryan_Dahl), the original creator of [NodeJS](https://nodejs.org/en/). It has several new advantages:

- Use of Promises
- Uses TypeScript out of the box
- no need for node_modules
- uses urls to load dependencies (might be a plus or minus).

Issues.Title: feat(ivy): index information about owning and imported NgModule
Issues.Body:
Add a information about the owning NgModule of a component and the
NgModule that the owner imports to the indexing API.

Matching selectors to class declarations across Angular compilation
units is currently very difficult, if possible at all. Providing
references to the owning and imported NgModules gives a workaround that
will work in many cases, at least for matching element selectors.
Following is an analysis of how this works on an indexer's side.

The idea is because selectors are unique in NgModules, when a selector
on a component is encountered an indexer implementation may emit the
selector information on the NgModule class declaration, for example
in a form like `$MODULE::selector::$SELECTOR`. When the selector is
later encountered in a template, references to
`$MODULE::selector::$SELECTOR` for each `$MODULE` in the imported
NgModule are optimistically emitted. Hanging references, of course, are
ignored.

This does not resolve issues of reexports and is a naive solution, but
will work for now.

Issues.Title: test: remove material-design-icons package as a development dependency
Issues.Body: The package is quite large at 33MB (46MB on disk and ~90K files).  The large size can occasionally cause package installation issues.  The package is also only used in one test that is already covered by an E2E test.  The E2E test does not require the package to be present for development as the test installs it within a generated project during execution.  This also has the benefit of testing the icons package in a more real world use case; as well as allowing the test to serve as a guide for a user to add the package to their own application.

Issues.Title: feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): add defer attributes to classic scripts
Issues.Body: This change synchronizes the behavior of classic scripts and module scripts (`type="module"`).  Module scripts are deferred by default.  Also, certain injected scripts are not considered module scripts even in a ES2015+ build due to the strict mode behavior of module scripts.  Deferring such scripts also ensures consistent execution in those scenarios.

Issues.Title: ng serve adding HTTP response headers
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
```
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [x] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> A clear and concise description of the problem or missing capability...
First, I'm a huge fan of the CLI.  The proxy.conf.json feature in "ng serve" has saved me many hours of work dealing with CORS related issues.  However, it would be nice to be able to add a predefined collection of HTTP headers to the proxied responses.  In my particular instance, it would allow me to cache my dev server responses while I'm working.  I imagine that it would speed up development for many.

### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> If you have a solution in mind, please describe it.
I know that the WebPack dev server allows for this:
https://webpack.js.org/configuration/dev-server/#devserverheaders-

I'm not sure how this is translated to the proxy.conf.json file, but I can visualize it would look something like this:

{
 "/employeesWebApi": {
    "target": "https://xxxxxxxx.azurewebsites.net",
    "secure": true,
    "pathRewrite": {
      "^/employeesWebApi": ""
    },
    "changeOrigin": true,
    "headers":{
      "Cache-Control" : "public, max-age=31536000"
    }
  }
}


### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?
Hot module reloading would be an alternative but I haven't been able to get this to work with NGRX, Angular 8 and the CLI.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ng serve adding HTTP response headers" (#15095)

Issues.Title: feat(@ngtools/webpack): show warning when large CSS are included in c‚Ä¶
Issues.Body:
‚Ä¶omponents

It‚Äôs very easy to inadvertently import toplevel css in component styles. Since component css is standalone and self-contained, it will never be shared between components and remains as a single large bundle for each component. This in turn adds a large amount of code that must be processed and increases bundle size.

Related to: TOOL-949

Issues.Title: "start_url" in manifest file is not updated by a build with --baseHref
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [X] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? No ### Description I have a brand new Angular project where I added PWA features via the add schematic `ng add angular/pwa`. In the web manifest file the "start_url" property is set to "/" by default. If I run a PROD build changing the baseHref (`ng build --prod --baseHref "/myDemo/"`), the asset URLs in the `ngsw.json` file are correctly update, but not the "start_url" property in the manifest file. It must be updated manually. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 1. Create a new Angular app: `ng new myDemo` 2. Add PWA features: `ng add @angular/pwa` 3. Make a prod build using baseHref option: `ng build --prod --baseHref "/myDemo/"` ## üî• Exception or Error The `manifest.webmanifest` file is copied in the dist folder, but its start_url property does not reflect the value used for the baseHref option. ## üåç Your Environment 

Angular CLI: 8.1.1
Node: 12.3.1
OS: darwin x64
Angular: 8.2.0-next.1
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router, service-worker

Issues.Title: Safari 10.1 fails differential loading browser test
Issues.Body:
Safari 10.1 is currently the only browser failing the newly added browser testing for differential loading.  A newly generated application created from a master version of the CLI is used as the system under test.

The following error is generated upon execution of the application's E2E test:
```
undefined is not an object (evaluating 'd.prototype[b].apply')
```

Further investigation is required.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Safari 10.1 fails differential loading browser test" (#15084)

Issues.Title: Rebuild should be shorter because the lazy chunks have not changed
Issues.Body:

Issues.Title: ES2015 + emitDecoratorMetadata causes Cannot access before intialization
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package @angular/compiler ### Is this a regression? No, but this is more relevant now because angular-cli permits ES2015 targets. ### Description When targeting ES2015, emitDecoratorMetadata causes a ReferenceError. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://github.com/pauldraper/angular-decorator-metadata ``` ng serve ``` Load in browser. ## üî• Exception or Error 
main.js:98 Uncaught ReferenceError: Cannot access 'AppService' before initialization
    at Module../src/app.component.ts (main.js:98)
    at __webpack_require__ (runtime.js:80)
    at Module../src/app.module.ts (main.js:123)
    at __webpack_require__ (runtime.js:80)
    at Module../src/main.ts (main.js:157)
    at __webpack_require__ (runtime.js:80)
    at Object.0 (main.js:174)
    at __webpack_require__ (runtime.js:80)
    at checkDeferredModules (runtime.js:46)
    at Array.webpackJsonpCallback [as push] (runtime.js:33)
## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** Angular 8.1.1 **Anything else relevant?** Removing emitDecoratorMetadata, or targeting es5 fixes the problem.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "ES2015 + emitDecoratorMetadata causes Cannot access before intialization" (#15077)

Issues.Title: Include ScopedTree in the public API of @angular-devkit/schematics
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
```
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è-->
While creating schematics for a project on top of the `ng-new` and `ng-add` I needed to execute a sequence of rules scoped to a subfolder in the workspace. I noticed that there is a `ScopedTree` in the schematics package, but it is not exposed in the public API. I used it to create a `scopedToDir` utility:

```
export function scopedToDir(dir: string, rule: Rule): Rule {
    return (tree: Tree, context: SchematicContext) => {
        return callRule(rule, of(new ScopedTree(tree, dir)), context).pipe(
            map(() => tree));
    };
}
```

Which can then be used like this:

```
scopedToDir(dir, chain([
    createSomeFiles(),
    modifySomeFiles(),
    foo()
]))
```

### Describe the solution you'd like
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> If you have a solution in mind, please describe it.
It would be nice if the `ScopedTree` would be exported in the public API as it offers useful functionality.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?

Currently, I'm importing like this:
```
import { ScopedTree } from '@angular-devkit/schematics/src/tree/scoped';
```
But I think this is like relying on undocumented functionality, which may change at any time, without warning.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Include ScopedTree in the public API of @angular-devkit/schematics" (#15079)

Issues.Title: refactor(tree): avoid improper query usage
Issues.Body:
The way things are set up at the moment we have a `CdkNestedTreeNode` which uses a `ContentChildren` to find a `CdkTreeNodeOutlet` so that it knows where to render its content. On top of this we have a `MatNestedTreeNode` which extends `CdkNestedTreeNode` and defines it's own query at the same property, but looking for a `MatTreeNodeOutlet`. With this setup it means that both `CdkNestedTreeNode` and `MatNestedTreeNode` are trying to write to the same `nodeOutlet` property and it's by pure coincidence that it works. This is very fragile and it isn't guaranteed to work in future versions of the framework.

These changes fix the issue by removing the query from the `MatNestedTreeNode` and providing the `MatTreeNodeOutlet` as a `CdkTreeNodeOutlet` so that the query on the `CdkNestedTreeNode` can pick it up.

cc @pkozlowski-opensource
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(tree): avoid improper query usage" (#16540)

Issues.Title: fix(ng-update): material update fails due to circular dependency
Issues.Body:
Currently running `ng update` for both Material and CDK fails because there
is a circular dependency in the CDK schematics that cause the update-tool
exports to be not available to the Material ng-update schematic.

Without putting to much effort into ensuring no circular dependencies, this
commit also sets up Madge to avoid such issues in the future.

![test](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4987015/61322266-8d4a2a80-a80d-11e9-86ce-440941bd26ac.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(ng-update): material update fails due to circular dependency" (#16538)

Issues.Title: fix(drag-drop): fix drag start delay behavior to allow scrolling (#16224)
Issues.Body:
I tried fixing the scrolling issue on mobile devices with my previous PR (#16228), but it did not work on iOS. There was also a bug with scrolling after the item has been dragged once. The native drag interactions were not toggled when the drag sequence is ended¬≠.

In order to fix the iOS issue, we prevent default behaviour of pointer events fired after
the drag sequence has been started instead of only initialized.

Issues.Title: build: allow inspecting test nodejs process w/ bazel
Issues.Body:
Adds a new `debug` configuration for Bazel that can be used to
open the Chrome Devtools Debugger in order to debug a bazel
test that runs with NodeJS. This is similar to what `angular/angular`
provides.

*Note*: This does not make debugging for web test suites easier. For
web test suites we need to find a better solution. I have something in mind
where developers can run `bazel run` instead of `bazel test` to open the
karma test suite in non-capture mode (allowing easy debugging)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: allow inspecting test nodejs process w/ bazel" (#16525)

Issues.Title: Drag and drop scrolling container
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

In version 8.1.0 of components, the new scrolling feature enables auto scrolling of the cdkDropList or the viewport. It would be awesome to specify the drag scroll container if the scrolling container is not the droplist or the viewport. 

Cdk drag scroll enables this feature using the vsDragScrollContainer directive,
https://github.com/volser/cdk-drag-scroll

#### Use Case

Container with scrolling containing a droplist that can't be scrolled with a viewport that cant be scrolled. Specifying the container and hooking up on its scrolling should enable scrolling.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Drag and drop scrolling container" (#16535)

Issues.Title: matNativeControl shows value that does not match model when options are changed, makes displayed option unselectable
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-native-select-option

Steps to reproduce:
1. Press Options 1 or Options 2, which changes the options displayed by both the native select and the mat-select.
2. Observe that the underlying control's value is null, but the native select shows the first option out of its options as the selected item.
3. Attempt to select the displayed value in the native dropdown. It appears selected,
4. Change focus away from the native control. The required validator will fire and the control will be invalid.
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

No option should be displayed as no option was selected, as per the mat-select behaviour. 


#### Actual Behavior

The native control displays a value that does not match its model. Further, the option that is displayed can't actually be selected without selecting another option first.


#### Environment

- Angular: 7.2.15
- CDK/Material: 7.3.7
- Browser(s): Firefox 68 64 bit, Chrome 75.0.3770.100 64 bit
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10 1903 18362.207
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "matNativeControl shows value that does not match model when options are changed, makes displayed option unselectable" (#16519)
